author: By Max Fisher
title: Does Abe Shooting Reflect Success of Japan’s Gun Laws, Not Failure?
description: A crude weapon. Minimal security. One death. A closer look at the details of the assassination of Shinzo Abe may actually underscore the effectiveness of Japan’s restrictions.
content: The assassination of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe in Japan may look like a rebuke of the country’s famously stringent gun laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Abe was a transformational figure in Japan.
description: In his record-breaking run as prime minister, Shinzo Abe never achieved his goal of revising Japan’s Constitution to transform his country into what the Japanese call a “normal nation,” able to employ its military to back up its national interests like any other.
content: In his record-breaking run as prime minister, Shinzo Abe never achieved his goal of revising Japan’s Constitution to transform his country into what the Japanese call a “normal nation,” able to employ its military to back up its national interests like any other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich, Daisuke Wakabayashi, Hikari Hida and Hisako Ueno
title: After a Brutal Assassination, Japan Mourns and Carries On
description: A day after former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s killing, Japan, where gun violence of any kind is rare, was just beginning to process the shock.
content: TOKYO — A day after the assassination of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe at a political rally, the police in Japan faced sharp questions about the adequacy of his security, even as parliamentary candidates resumed campaigning on Saturday in a sign that despite the tragedy, political life was carrying on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Administration Signals Support for Controversial Alaska Oil Project
description: The administration issued an environmental review that represents a key step toward starting the Willow project. Opponents say drilling would violate Biden’s pledge to rein in fossil fuels.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration took a key step toward approving a huge oil drilling project in the North Slope of Alaska, angering environmental activists who said allowing it to go forward would make a mockery of President Biden’s climate-change promise to end new oil leases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Mike Brito, Influential Dodger Scout in Mexico, Dies at 87
description: He signed many players who reached the major leagues, most notably Fernando Valenzuela, who won the 1981 Rookie of the Year and Cy Young Awards.
content: Mike Brito, the influential Cuban-born Los Angeles Dodgers scout who in Mexico discovered the pitcher Fernando Valenzuela, whose sensational 1981 season uncorked the delirious fan reaction known as “Fernandomania,” died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Where My Research Has Taken Me Lately
description: What I’m reading, what I’m thinking.
content: Instead of an extended take on a particular issue or question, I thought I would use this weekend’s newsletter to share some of what I’ve been reading this summer. My job for The Times involves a lot of research, and while some of what I learn shows up in my work in the form of quotes and other direct references, a lot of it doesn’t. You can think of this reading list as a glimpse into where my head is at right now, and what I am thinking.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Single Moms Can’t Get Aid From Beijing
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 9, 2022.
content: “If you really want to have a baby without a man you have to fight for it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan DiTrolio
title: The Last Days of Suburban Office Parks
description: With remote work and new norms, a concept that arose in postwar America is dying off. Emily Badger, who reported on the trend for The Upshot, shares more.
content: The scene is familiar to anyone who has watched “The Office” or worked a 9-to-5 in the last 50 years. Cubicles. Poor lighting. And, out the window, a view of a parking lot and sprawling green grass. This is the image of the classic suburban office building, whose popularity rose in postwar America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How Do I Prevent My Newspaper Deliveries From Being Stolen?
description: Without the cooperation of building management, a delivery person has no option but to dump papers in a spot where anyone can grab them.
content: Q: When I moved into my rent-stabilized apartment in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, three years ago, my daily newspaper was delivered to my door. The building owner has since died, and his son, who inherited the property, has refused to allow the newspaper delivery person to enter the building, so the papers are now dumped in the outer lobby. If I don’t pick mine up at 6:30 every morning, it’s often filched. What recourse do I have?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Kate Conger
title: The Elon Musk-Twitter Saga Now Moves to the Courts
description: Most legal experts say Twitter has the upper hand. But Musk revels in brinkmanship.
content: Now that Elon Musk has signaled his intent to walk away from his $44 billion offer to buy Twitter, the fate of the influential social media network will be determined by what may be an epic court battle, involving months of expensive litigation and high-stakes negotiations by elite lawyers on both sides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Sri Lanka’s prime minister is no stranger to political shifts.
description: Ranil Wickremesinghe, who had been in office only since May, said he would resign.
content: One of the political casualties in Sri Lanka on Saturday was Ranil Wickremesinghe, a prime minister six times over whose leadership has been equated with Sri Lanka’s economic ambitions as well as its collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: The Rajapaksa family has dominated Sri Lankan politics.
description: The Rajapaksas have cast a shadow over politics in Sri Lanka for much of the past two decades, and in recent years, they have increasingly run the government as a family business.
content: The Rajapaksa family has dominated Sri Lanka’s politics for much of the past two decades, and in recent years, it has increasingly run the island nation’s government as a family business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Bortz
title: Dressing Your Home for Success
description: Removing dark curtains or adding plants can attract more buyers to your property — and help you make more money off the sale, industry professionals say.
content: Even in today’s red-hot market, where buyers are fighting tooth and nail for a limited supply of homes, how a property looks — in listing photos and in person — is important. This is where staging comes in. “It doesn’t matter whether it’s a seller’s market or a buyer’s market,” says Monica P. Murphy, the owner of Preferred Staging, a home staging company in Potomac Falls, Va. “What staging does is it makes your home more presentable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: 50 million remain under a heat advisory this weekend.
description: The dangerous heat wave shows no signs of letting up as it affects states including Texas, Arizona, Alabama and Colorado.
content: Millions of Americans will still be under a sweltering heat wave the rest of this weekend and into much of next week that the National Weather Service described as “oppressive” and “dangerous.” About 50 million people in the nation are under heat warnings or advisories, Frank Pereira, a meteorologist with the Weather Service said in an interview on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
title: Jan. 6 Panel Questions Cipollone on Pardons and Trump’s Election Claims
description: Pat A. Cipollone, the former White House counsel for President Donald J. Trump, appeared before the House committee investigating the Capitol attack for roughly eight hours on Friday.
content: WASHINGTON — Pat A. Cipollone, who served as White House counsel for President Donald J. Trump, was asked detailed questions on Friday about pardons, false election fraud claims and the former president’s pressure campaign against Vice President Mike Pence, according to three people familiar with his testimony before the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Reconstructing the Bronx Apartment Fire
description: Reporters, graphics editors and engineering experts collaborated to map how a fire in a Bronx high-rise killed 17 residents in January.
content: Anjali Singhvi said her heart sank when she saw a resident’s video of the stairwells at Twin Parks North West, the Bronx apartment building that in January became the site of one of the city’s deadliest blazes, leading to the deaths of 17 residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Ilana Marcus and Mary F. Calvert
title: ‘I Felt Trapped’: Sexual Abuse of Teens in the Military’s J.R.O.T.C. Program
description: Former students say military veterans who led J.R.O.T.C. classes in U.S. high schools fashioned themselves as mentors, then used their power to manipulate and abuse.
content: PICAYUNE, Miss. — With the rifle skills she honed in the Mississippi backwoods, Victoria Bauer had a path to escape the trap of drugs and dead-end jobs she saw most everywhere around her. Her future was in the Marines, she decided, and she had an idea about how to get there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: At 79, Biden Is Testing the Boundaries of Age and the Presidency
description: President Biden has said he plans to run for a second term, but his age has become an uncomfortable issue for him and his party.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Biden leaves Tuesday night for a four-day swing through the Middle East, he will presumably be more rested than he would have been had he followed the original plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Hisako Ueno
title: The suspect will be handed over to prosecutors on Sunday, the Nara police say.
description: Tetsuya Yamagami, 41, is accused of killing Shinzo Abe, Japan’s former prime minister.
content: Tetsuya Yamagami, the suspect in the assassination of Japan’s former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, will be detained and questioned by the police in the city of Nara for another night, then transferred to the custody of the local prosecutors’ office, the police said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: ‘The Sinker Is Going to Be My Ticket’
description: Clay Holmes knew what made him special as a pitcher. It took some time — and a trade to the Yankees — for that vision to become reality.
content: BOSTON — Clay Holmes threw a sinker from the first time he ever played catch. He was seven years old, he guessed, and his fingers felt comfortable along the seams, not across them. In time, the two-seam grip would give his pitches downward, tailing action, and give him a professional career — if only he could keep it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Lai and Ava Sasani
title: More Than 1,000 Protesters at White House Call on Biden to Protect Abortion Rights
description: The rally on Saturday, in which some demonstrators risked arrest, reflected activists’ growing frustration with the administration.
content: WASHINGTON — One day after President Biden issued an executive order designed to ensure access to abortion medication and emergency contraception, more than a thousand protesters gathered in front of the White House, with hundreds risking arrest by sitting at the building’s gates, to urge Mr. Biden to do more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suleman Anaya
title: The New New Haven
description: Unexpectedly, the Connecticut city has emerged, both because of and despite its association with Yale, as an affordable and dynamic home for artists of all kinds.
content: On a recent evening in the New Haven, Conn., Dixwell neighborhood, artists, students, academics and locals gathered in a large, state-of-the-art event space for a conversation with the photographer Dawoud Bey, 69, who is known for chronicling unseen facets of the Black experience in America. Using thoughtful, precise words, Bey — who has a rare command of language — described the ways in which a long tradition of Black cultural production informs his work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Schwartz
title: The Age of Distracti-pression
description: The pandemic’s true toll on mental health won’t be known for a long time, but data from the past two years indicates a rise — some of it sharp — in prescription drugs for conditions like A.D.H.D. and depression.
content: If you’re wondering which pills and how many of them Americans have relied upon to make ourselves feel better since Covid-19 arrived, the answer, in short, is yes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Ukraine dismisses its ambassador to Germany after controversial remarks.
description: Andriy Melnyk, an outspoken advocate for weapons for Ukraine, denied the role of a Ukrainian nationalist leader in the Holocaust, stoking outrage in Germany.
content: Volodymyr Zelensky, the president of Ukraine, fired his ambassador to Germany, a week after the diplomat gave an interview in which he defended the legacy of a World War II nationalist leader who collaborated with the Nazis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: U.C.L.A. and U.S.C., Welcome to the Big Ten. I Already Hate You.
description: It will be weird with these California schools in my conference, but I welcome the new rivalries.
content: My favorite college football team is the Michigan Wolverines, which makes the Big Ten my favorite conference. The oldest Division 1 athletic conference in the country, the association that would eventually be called the Big Ten was originally composed of Midwestern universities like Michigan (where, as regular readers know, I went), the University of Illinois and the University of Wisconsin, before adding Penn State in 1990 to make the Big Ten a conference of 11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Blinken presses his Chinese counterpart about the war.
description: NUSA DUA, Indonesia — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with his Chinese counterpart on Saturday, pressing him to “stand up” against Russia’s war in Ukraine while also extending a hand of cooperation amid a Biden administration campaign to stabilize its strained relationship with Beijing.
content: NUSA DUA, Indonesia — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with his Chinese counterpart on Saturday, pressing him to “stand up” against Russia’s war in Ukraine while also extending a hand of cooperation amid a Biden administration campaign to stabilize its strained relationship with Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Illustrious
description: Kevin G. Der’s Saturday puzzle comes with very few lifeboats.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I think this is the hardest Saturday grid we have seen in some months, but it’s been years since Kevin G. Der’s last solo Saturday puzzle, published back in 2018. Note the quadruple stacks, technical feats of construction, in this grid’s northeast and southwest corners. Also note the torrent of debuts — 11 in a 66-word puzzle — as well as a big bunch of oddities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and David E. Sanger
title: Ukraine and the Contest of Global Stamina
description: The conflict’s long-run trajectory seems increasingly likely to be shaped by whether the United States and its allies can maintain their military, political and financial commitments to holding off Russia.
content: WASHINGTON — Another day, another weapons shipment: On Friday, the Pentagon announced a new transfer of precision-guided shells and multiple rocket launchers to Ukraine, the latest armaments heading east. But will there come a day when that system begins to slow?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hikari Hida and Ben Dooley
title: Campaigns make their final push in Japan, undeterred by Abe’s assassination.
description: Shinzo Abe, Japan’s longest serving prime minister, was shot while campaigning for a candidate for the Upper House of Parliament.
content: TOKYO — Candidates for parliamentary election in Japan on Saturday rushed from rally to rally, hoping to appeal to voters during the final hours of the campaign period, just a day after the assassination of Shinzo Abe, Japan’s longest serving prime minister, sparked fears the campaign would be disrupted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: 13 Guns Used in Harlem Shootout, Police Say, Underscoring Deadly Threat
description: The tally shows how ubiquitous firearms, many illegal, are in New York, with more legal ones anticipated after a recent Supreme Court ruling.
content: Darius Lee, 21, a native son of Harlem and a basketball star at Houston Baptist University, was in a large group of revelers on a Sunday night last month, enjoying a beautiful Father’s Day weekend at a barbecue, when he was killed in a flurry of gunfire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: A Memory That Moves: A Decrepit Hong Kong Double-Decker Bus Gets New Life
description: When the pandemic cut their flight hours, two pilots spent months and hundreds of thousands of dollars reviving a vehicle that reminded them of a happier time in Hong Kong.
content: HONG KONG — Pedestrians stopped in their tracks and stared. Passengers in vehicles craned their necks and waved. Schoolboys in uniform ran like paparazzi angling for the perfect shot. They were all riveted by a cream-colored double-decker bus with ketchup-red trims on the top and bottom swerving last month into an open-air terminal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Rysman and Gus Powell
title: Don’t Toss Those Old Sneakers
description: After making a name for itself with $500 handmade sneakers, Golden Goose is turning its focus to repairs: “Someone who feels taken care of will always return,” its C.E.O. said.
content: This article is part of a series examining Responsible Fashion, and innovative efforts to address issues facing the fashion industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Laura Philpott
title: A Viral Essay Grows into a Hearty, Viable Collection
description: In “The Crane Wife,” CJ Hauser delves into issues of identity and connection with humor and grace.
content: In 2019, CJ Hauser’s essay “The Crane Wife” went viral, garnering more than a million views on The Paris Review’s website. Personally, I accounted for at least three of those views, as I read, reread aloud (exclaiming, “God, she’s good!” at the end), and then emailed several friends to demand they also read Hauser’s story about breaking off a wedding engagement, leaving the home she shared with her fiancé in upstate New York and going to Texas to research whooping cranes for her second novel. Still, when I found out Hauser had built a whole essay collection around that piece, I thought, Oh no.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Arizona Law Bans People From Recording Police Within Eight Feet
description: Civil rights and news media organizations have objected to the law, which is set to go into effect in September, as a violation of free speech protections.
content: The governor of Arizona has signed a measure into law that makes it illegal for people to record videos within eight feet of police activity, limiting efforts to increase transparency around law enforcement operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Valentino’s Roman Marvels
description: Expanding the meaning of couture, one ruffle and feather at a time.
content: ROME — The couture shows came to an end not in Paris but in Rome, with a river of gold ballroom chairs connecting the Piazza di Spagna at the foot of the Spanish Steps — the most famous people-watching and -posing staircase in Europe — to Piazza Mignanelli, where the Valentino headquarters stand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frederica Perera and Kari Nadeau
title: The Supreme Court Dealt a Terrible Blow to Children’s Health
description: We are now learning that climate change and air pollution can act together to increase health effects.
content: Climate change and air pollution — both largely driven by fossil fuel emissions — inflict a huge toll on the health of children. This is especially true within low-income communities and communities of color. The recent Supreme Court decision, West Virginia v. Environmental Protection Agency, that curtails the E.P.A.’s power to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from power plants will greatly exacerbate this harm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: With a Wimbledon Title, Elena Rybakina Finally Cracks a Smile
description: Rybakina’s victory at Wimbledon was deeply impressive but not the outcome that most in Centre Court or on the payrolls of the All England Club were yearning for.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Elena Rybakina’s surprise run to the Wimbledon title — full of overwhelming serves, timely winners and underrated defense — was a thing of cruel beauty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of July 4, 2022.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Alice Elliott Dark on ‘Fellowship Point’
description: Dark talks about her new novel, and Katherine Chen discusses “Joan,” her fictional imagining of Joan of Arc.
content: In Alice Elliott Dark’s second novel, “Fellowship Point,” Agnes Lee and Polly Wister have been friends for about 80 years. Their intertwined families own homes on a Maine peninsula, and some of the book’s drama stems from their efforts to preserve the land and keep it out of the hands of developers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: A shocking crime with many unanswered questions.
description: As Japan’s former prime minister, Shinzo Abe, spoke to the crowd in the city of Nara, a man in cargo pants and a grey shirt approached from behind, carrying a crude handmade gun. He shot Mr. Abe twice.
content: As Japan’s former prime minister, Shinzo Abe, spoke to the crowd in the city of Nara, a man in cargo pants and a grey shirt approached from behind, carrying a crude handmade gun. He shot Mr. Abe twice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriane Quinlan
title: When a Professor Trades the Academy for an Art Career of His Own
description: For Thomas Woodruff, retirement from teaching offered the very thing he’d been trying to instill in his students: artistic freedom.
content: When New York City went into lockdown in the spring of 2020, Thomas Woodruff started sketching dinosaurs. Not as a child might doodle a T. rex, but as an artist drawing a self-portrait. At 62, he was 20 years into his career as the head of the illustration and cartooning departments at the School of Visual Arts, and he’d begun to worry that he and his students came from different eras. One class failed to recognize Picasso’s “Guernica” but could name Forky, the Picasso-inspired spork character in Toy Story 4. “It doesn’t count anymore if you’re a gay man of a certain age who went through the AIDS crisis,” he says from the same drafting table in his studio, a repurposed barn in Germantown, N.Y., where for more than a year he taught via Zoom. “It’s something that’s just kind of like, ‘Well, you’re a dinosaur.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Kandell
title: Luis Echeverría Alvarez, Former President of Mexico, Dies at 100
description: He had faced accusations that, as interior secretary, he was responsible for repressing protests before the 1968 Olympics that ended in a massacre.
content: Luis Echeverría Alvarez, who steered Mexico on a stormy left-wing course in the 1970s as president and who never escaped the shadow of a massacre before the 1968 Olympics, died on Friday at his home in Cuernavaca. He was 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Questions Arise About Abe’s Security Protection After Assassination
description: Numerous videos show the gunman walking unobstructed past security before pointing a large handmade gun in the direction of the former prime minister.
content: A day after former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was gunned down in broad daylight, a stunned nation is questioning how the gunman was able to approach one of Japan’s most prominent politicians and fire two shots from close range without security stepping in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada’s Slow and Troubled Path to Rapid Transit
description: Partnerships with the private sector were supposed to protect cities from cost overruns and delays. That hasn’t always worked out.
content: Canada is on a mass transit building spree. But to say that things are not going according to plan would be an understatement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Summer Travel, Made Easy
description: You need not travel far to experience the delights of summer.
content: A friend texted me last weekend from a departure lounge in Kennedy Airport. “Um three hours and counting …” she wrote of her L.A.-bound flight’s delay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Euan Ward
title: An American arrested in Russia last year was sentenced by the court handling Brittney Griner’s case.
description: Marc Fogel, a teacher and former U.S. Embassy staff member, was convicted on charges of drug smuggling in Russia. He was sentenced to 14 years in prison.
content: With the spotlight on the case of Brittney Griner, the American basketball star who has been detained in Russia since February, the sentencing of a former U.S. Embassy worker in Russia last month on similar drug charges has his loved ones also pleading for him to be allowed to return home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrice Peck
title: Finding My Joy at Essence Festival
description: I relished the community I had been missing on my first trip to the famous New Orleans gathering.
content: The first five notes of “Swag Surfin’” rang out in the cavernous New Orleans Ernest N. Morial Convention Center — a rallying call for a swarm of people to a makeshift dance floor. Doing what one naturally does when the F.L.Y. (Fast Life Yungstaz) 2009 hit comes on, I locked damp arms with a stranger on either side of me — and they with those beside them. Entranced, we swayed in slow, hypnotic harmony until the beat finally crashed down, our cue to rock our beautiful Black bodies back and forth and ride the booming bass as one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Judge and Stanton Will Start for A.L. in All-Star Game
description: The Yankees sluggers will join Mike Trout of the Angels in the American League’s starting outfield.
content: The Yankees will have two-thirds of the American League’s starting outfield in this year’s All-Star Game, with Aaron Judge and Giancarlo Stanton taking the corner spots on either side of Mike Trout of the Los Angeles Angels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabrielle Glaser
title: When the Results of a DNA Test Change the Family Tree
description: In their memoirs, Carmen Rita Wong and Chrysta Bilton open up about how they learned of secrets, lies and unkept promises.
content: A few years ago, a friend of mine sent a vial of his saliva to a DNA testing company hoping to gain clues about his late father’s Italian ancestry. The results were a shock. He had no Italian blood at all. The man who’d raised him from infancy, and whose name he carried, was not his biological father. After weeks of checking his results against those of cousins with whom he shared no DNA, he mustered the courage to ask his nonagenarian mother about the findings. “So I had an affair!” she said. “Whoever thought there’d be 23andMe, for chrissakes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
title: The president is defying calls to step down, despite mounting public pressure.
description: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa has defied intensifying calls for his departure, even as public pressure over the past five months has forced several members of his family, including his brother Mahinda Rajapaksa, who was the prime minister, to resign.
content: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa has defied intensifying calls for his departure, even as public pressure over the past five months has forced several members of his family, including his brother Mahinda Rajapaksa, who was the prime minister, to resign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Companies’ Climate Promises Face a Wild Card: Farmers
description: Some of the largest companies in the U.S. have pledged to adopt climate-friendly agricultural techniques. But some farmers say they haven’t provided enough incentive.
content: Driving rain pelted the windows of “the Tower,” a second-story glass enclosure in Ray Gaesser’s home that provides a view for miles of the gentle, rolling fields around Corning, Iowa. Inside, away from the elements, Mr. Gaesser pondered what the coming year might bring for farmers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: What Are Spam Bots and Why They’re an Issue in Elon Musk’s Twitter Deal
description: Bots can tweet at people, share tweets, follow and be followed by other people. And there are good bots and bad.
content: On Friday, the tech billionaire Elon Musk announced that he was terminating a $44 billion deal to buy Twitter. The reason, he said, was an ongoing disagreement over the number of spam bot accounts on the platform. Now, the issue of what constitutes a spam bot account, and how many currently exist on Twitter, is likely to be at the heart of the legal battles between Mr. Musk and Twitter over the fraught deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: Amid the Summer Flying ‘Meltdown,’ Add Lost Luggage
description: Surging air travel demand and airport staffing shortages have made this a bedeviling season when it comes to missing luggage. Here’s what to know if your bag doesn’t arrive when you do.
content: The Apple AirTag tracking device that Lily Datta had placed in her luggage before leaving Cleveland on June 27 showed the suitcase had arrived in Paris the following day. That perplexed Ms. Datta because she and her family had no plans to go to Paris. Their destination was Vienna, with stops in Washington, D.C. and Barcelona to get there, but not Paris. It was the family’s first foray abroad since the start of the pandemic, a trip to celebrate her son Dev’s high school graduation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Ben Dooley and Hikari Hida
title: The assassination shocked a nearly gun-free Japan.
description: The assassination of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe during a campaign rally in western Japan was especially hard to fathom because it involved a gun — a type of crime that is extremely rare in a country with some of the most stringent laws on buying and owning firearms.
content: The assassination of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe during a campaign rally in western Japan was especially hard to fathom because it involved a gun — a type of crime that is extremely rare in a country with some of the most stringent laws on buying and owning firearms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Holleyman
title: America Can’t Allow China to Keep Crushing Our Solar Energy Industry
description: The Biden administration is taking a gamble that furthers our reliance on China without providing the essential elements to build our domestic solar industry.
content: A robust solar energy industry in the United States is crucial to the nation’s goal of a low-carbon future. But the prospects for solar energy are not looking bright these days, because the United States has allowed China to dominate the industry. Failure to create a strong domestic solar manufacturing industry leaves the United States and our carbon-reduction goals not just dependent on China, but also vulnerable should China block or threaten to block its solar exports as a form of retaliation in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Behind Russia’s ‘pause’ are signs of a troubled effort to regroup.
description: The weapons and personnel Russia may be turning to, analysts say, suggest that Moscow’s next assault may not be as fierce as it promised.
content: With Russian forces in the middle of a purported “operational pause,” some Ukrainians in the country’s battered eastern frontline regions are questioning what that means at a time when their towns are still coming under continued shelling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Tony Sirico, an Eccentric Gangster on ‘The Sopranos,’ Dies at 79
description: A familiar face in Woody Allen movies, he became widely known for his portrayal of Paulie Walnuts on the hit HBO series.
content: Tony Sirico, the actor best known for playing the eccentric gangster Paulie Walnuts on the hit HBO series “The Sopranos,” died on Friday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tobias Harris
title: The Postwar Japan That Shinzo Abe Built
description: After waging an often lonely fight, Abe died just as the Japanese people were possibly coming to appreciate his vision of a strong state.
content: In January 2007, only a few months after he was elected, at 52, as Japan’s youngest prime minister of the postwar era, Shinzo Abe delivered a speech outlining his policy priorities after the opening ceremony of the 166th session of Japan’s Diet, the country’s parliamentary body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: How Mexico’s Top Justice, Raised Catholic, Became an Abortion Rights Champion
description: Influenced by feminists close to him, the chief of the country’s Supreme Court helped pave the way for decriminalization of the procedure.
content: MEXICO CITY — When the chief justice of Mexico’s Supreme Court began voting in favor of abortion rights, his toughest opponents were the people closest to him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Denali National Park, in Alaska, reinstates a mask mandate in the busy summer season.
description: As counties report elevated levels of transmission, national parks are once again requiring masks in gift shops, on tour buses and other indoor spaces.
content: With coronavirus cases increasing in its immediate vicinity in Alaska, the vast Denali National Park and Preserve reimposed a mask mandate on Friday for federal buildings and on park buses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Emile Ducke
title: ‘It’s Like Parallel Realities’: Rituals of Life and Death Blur in a Vibrant Ukrainian City
description: In Lviv, babies are born in a hospital just steps away from the military cemetery where Ukraine’s young soldiers are laid to rest.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — The tiny wail of newborn babies echoes out from the incubators and cribs lining a small room with mint green walls in a maternity hospital in Lviv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Boris Johnson May Be Fading Out, but Not the Divisions He Stoked
description: Long after he is gone, his successors will be wrestling over his signature project, Brexit, and the insoluble issues it raised.
content: LONDON — The swift, stinging downfall of Boris Johnson this past week removes a uniquely polarizing figure from British politics. But it does not remove the divisive issues that Mr. Johnson confronted — and in many cases, exploited — as he engineered Britain’s departure from the European Union two and a half years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: Why Does It Take Federal Intervention to Fix the N.Y.P.D.?
description: The work of holding law enforcement agencies accountable is arduous but vital.
content: The saga of the Special Victims Division is the latest illustration of the extraordinary measures required to meaningfully reform the nation’s largest police department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Movin’ On Up
description: Christina Iverson brings Scott Hogan into the big leagues with a collaborative puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Let this puzzle encourage anyone who’s had a crossword submission (or two, or four) rejected, or anyone who’s sitting on a great theme or clue set but needs a partner in crime to make a puzzle happen. Scott Hogan, a patent lawyer from Midland, Mich., went through the editorial wringer before connecting with Christina Iverson, a beloved Sunday puzzle fixture, via the Cruciverb Facebook group. This grid is the result. It’s a hoot, and there are more forthcoming from this pair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carolyn Wilke
title: It Hides Under the Soil With a Bottomless Appetite for Meat
description: Among the numerous carnivorous pitcher plant species, scientists say this is the first that lays its traps underground.
content: A newly discovered pitcher plant keeps its hunger for insects on the down low: It’s the first such plant known to grow working traps underground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Russeth
title: With Sign Language and Sound, an Artist Upends Audience Perceptions
description: Christine Sun Kim’s poetic and political art pushes viewers to consider the limits, and misunderstandings, that come with communication in any language, whether spoken or signed.
content: Last summer, a small plane hauled a sign with an intriguing phrase over Manchester, England: “The Sound of Smiling.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh
title: Sri Lanka’s economy is grinding to a halt without fuel.
description: Acute shortages have meant that medicines can’t be transported and fresh produce from farms can’t make it to cities.
content: One of the biggest reasons Sri Lankan residents took to the streets on Saturday is the country’s desperate need for fuel and other energy supplies. The South Asian nation has run out of foreign currency to pay for fuel, bringing its economy grinding to a halt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Steven Erlanger and Catherine Porter
title: Blinken Presses China’s Top Diplomat on Ukraine but Stresses Cooperation
description: At a G20 meeting, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken sought to cool tensions with Beijing in an effort to further isolate Russia. He met resistance.
content: NUSA DUA, Indonesia — The battle in Ukraine shifted to a geopolitical front on Saturday, as Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with the Chinese foreign minister at the end of a global summit in Indonesia, pressing his counterpart to join the United States  and “stand up” against Russia’s war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Albert Jones
title: The End of Roe Doesn’t Need to Bring an Increase in Maternal Mortality
description: Many of Europe’s abortion laws are stricter than many Americans may realize, but maternal health outcomes in Europe are much better.
content: It has been argued repeatedly that without access to abortion, the health of women will suffer and women will die. This fear is expressed overtly by the three dissenting justices in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, the decision that overturned Roe v. Wade last month. They cite experts who say that “a ban on abortions increases maternal mortality by 21 percent.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Fears of Another Gas Shock Drive Biden to Seek Price Cap on Russian Oil
description: Negotiating and selling the plan is a crucial task facing Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen as she travels to Asia in hopes of averting $7 a gallon gasoline.
content: WASHINGTON — Relief at the gas pump coupled with this past week’s news that businesses continue to hire at a blistering clip have tempered many economists’ fears that America is heading into a downturn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: The Nice-Guy Lawyer for America’s Tabloid Villains
description: The sweet spot of Arthur Aidala’s law practice is a headline-grabbing defendant who is hated by many. Somehow, that doesn’t mean people hate him.
content: Even when there are few cameras around, Arthur L. Aidala, 54, is camera-ready, dressed in a light-blue pinstripe suit with a purple pocket square and tie on a sunny June day. He’s a lawyer who welcomes press attention, but on this particular day he was worried about the way it can make a difficult job harder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Florida Man Sentenced to 20 Years for Uploading Bomb-Making Video
description: Federal prosecutors said the man, Romeo Xavier Langhorne, 32, had pledged support to ISIS and uploaded a video he hoped would help the group make and use bombs.
content: A Florida man who had pledged support to ISIS was sentenced on Thursday to 20 years in prison for uploading a video he believed would help the terrorist group make bombs, the federal authorities said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Just Months After the Last Floods, It’s the ‘Same Thing Again’
description: The toll of recurring disasters is starting to show among the residents of New South Wales, with many desperate for a break from overflowing rivers and wildfires.
content: “Every time it’s flooded it’s gotten higher and higher,” said April Harley, 38, a resident of Camden who has experienced four floods in the last four months. “It’s scary.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Invisibility, a Hippo and Antiques
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
content: Hello, readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: Jake Paul Is Aiming for Boxing Legitimacy, and Collecting Seashells
description: The social media star is preparing to fight his first opponent with professional boxing experience: Hasim Rahman Jr., who is 12-1. “I’ve been waiting to take his head off,” Paul said in an interview.
content: Jake Paul will get a chance next month to prove he’s not a boxing dilettante.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Hank Goldberg, Betting Maven and Sports Radio Star, Dies at 82
description: A New Jersey fan of sports and gambling who became one of the country’s top television handicappers: What are the odds?
content: Hank Goldberg, a prickly, bombastic and witty sports talk radio and television personality in Miami who became nationally known for handicapping horse races and N.F.L. games on ESPN, died on Monday, his 82nd birthday, at his home in Las Vegas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
title: Sri Lanka’s Leader Will Resign, Ally Says, After Protesters Storm Residence
description: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa will step down on Wednesday, according to the speaker of Parliament, amid fury over the economic crisis.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — With his home overrun by protesters, his powerful family on the run and the nation he once controlled in revolt against him, President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka agreed to resign on Saturday, according to the country’s top lawmaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Elena Rybakina Wins Wimbledon and Her First Grand Slam Title
description: Rybakina, who was born and raised in Russia, started representing Kazakhstan after the Russian tennis federation gave up on her. She beat Ons Jabeur in three sets to win the women’s singles title.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — There was no way anyone could have known four years ago, when the Russian-born-and-raised Elena Rybakina decided to play tennis for Kazakhstan that the move would pay off as fortuitously as it did in the summer of 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Stapinski
title: Where Is Pete Panto?
description: A union leader on the Brooklyn docks disappeared 81 years ago, presumably murdered by the mob.
content: On a dreary day in the autumn of 2020, Joseph Sciorra took a walk through St. Charles Cemetery on Long Island. Dr. Sciorra, like many trapped inside during the pandemic, had added cemetery strolls to his list of safe activities. But at St. Charles, he was on a mission. He was looking for the grave of a man named Pete Panto.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly and Maggie Haberman
title: Liz Cheney’s Latest Fans: Democratic Donors
description: Despite policy disagreements, donors like Jeffrey Katzenberg are backing the Wyoming Republican because of her role on the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack.
content: WASHINGTON — As one of the nation’s biggest Democratic donors, the film producer Jeffrey Katzenberg helped make Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton into Hollywood darlings. But this year, he is backing a surprise candidate: Representative Liz Cheney, the staunchly conservative Wyoming Republican.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Bill J. Allen, Alaska Businessman at the Center of Scandal, Dies at 85
description: He was one of the state’s most powerful figures, but his extensive corruption schemes brought him down — and took several politicians with him.
content: Bill J. Allen, an itinerant pipe fitter who rose to be one of the most powerful men in Alaska and a dominant figure in the state’s oil industry, then fell from grace in a spectacular bribery and corruption scheme that also took down a U.S. senator, died on June 29. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Aboard a ‘Hot Dog Bus’ in Hong Kong
description: “Hot dog buses,” nicknamed for their lack of air-conditioning, have not picked up passengers in Hong Kong for 10 years.  Join me for a ride on one.
content: “Hot dog buses,” nicknamed for their lack of air-conditioning, have not picked up passengers in Hong Kong for 10 years.  Join me for a ride on one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Almer Durston
title: Mourning After a Holiday Shooting
description: Highland Park residents are mourning and responding after a Fourth of July mass shooting.
content: Highland Park residents are mourning and responding after a Fourth of July mass shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Protesters in Sri Lanka Storm Presidential Residence
description: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka agreed to step down after what appeared to be one of the largest protests yet, following months of demonstrations fueled by the nation’s economic crisis.
content: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka agreed to step down after what appeared to be one of the largest protests yet, following months of demonstrations fueled by the nation’s economic crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Are ‘Women’ Being Erased?
description: Readers discuss a column by Pamela Paul that objected to a war on women from both the far right and far left.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 9, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 9, 2022.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about areas of eastern Ukraine that Russia’s invasion has left largely devoid of people and industry misstated the location of the conference where Ukraine’s prime minister, Denys Shmyhal, described the cost of rebuilding his country. It was in Switzerland, not Italy.
source.name: The New York Times
